data.source: Unacast anonymized cell phone mobility data; American Community Survey (ACS) 2014–2018 (5-year averages); MIT Election Data and Science Lab (2016 county-level vote share); 2010 Census (rurality)
data.wave_or_subset: Mobility change measured March 19–28, 2020 relative to matched days of a pre-COVID-19 reference week; ACS 2014–2018; 2016 U.S. presidential vote share; 2010 Census rurality.
data.sample_size: 3,037 counties (mobility estimates based on 15–17 million anonymized cell phone users per day).
data.access_details: Unacast provided their social distancing dataset for research use (acknowledged in paper); no further access details provided.
data.notes: Negative values in the outcome indicate greater social distancing. The median county experienced a 27.3 percentage-point decrease in mobility during March 19–28. Data do not sample all cell-phone users and do not reflect non-users; potential omitted-variable and ecological biases noted.

method.description: Cross-sectional analysis linking county-level mobility changes (as a proxy for social distancing) to socioeconomic status and political orientation. The study used Unacast mobility data to compute percentage-point changes in average distance traveled (March 19–28, 2020 vs. a pre-COVID reference week), and related these to county per capita income and 2016 Trump vote share using OLS regressions with state fixed effects, adjusting for sociodemographic and labor-market covariates and rurality.
steps: Obtain county-level mobility data from Unacast for March 19–28, 2020 and a pre-COVID-19 reference week.
Compute percentage-point change in average distance traveled relative to matched days in the reference week.
Merge county-level exposures: per capita income (ACS 2014–2018) and 2016 Trump vote share (MIT Election Data and Science Lab).

Merge covariates: percentage male, Black, Hispanic; age distribution (percent for each decade of life); share with college degree; employment shares in retail, transportation, and health/education/social services (ACS); rurality from 2010 Census.

Estimate cross-sectional OLS regressions of change in mobility on exposures, adjusting for covariates, rurality, and state fixed effects. Coefficients scaled to interquartile-range changes in predictors.
Summarize associations and interpret signs where negative values indicate greater social distancing.
method.models: Cross-sectional ordinary least squares regressions with state fixed effects; coefficients interpreted per interquartile-range change in predictors.
method.outcome_variable: Percentage-point change in average county mobility during March 19–28, 2020 relative to a pre-COVID reference week (negative values indicate greater social distancing).
method.independent_variables: Per capita income; 2016 county-level share of votes for President Trump.
method.control_variables: Percentage male; percentage Black; percentage Hispanic; age distribution (percentage in each decade of life); share of adults with college degree; employment shares in retail, transportation, and health/education/social services; percentage rural; state fixed effects.

results.summary: Counties with higher per capita income engaged in more social distancing, while counties with greater Republican (Trump) vote share engaged in less social distancing. These associations persisted after adjustment for sociodemographic and labor-market characteristics and state fixed effects. Higher shares of racial minorities and residents without college degrees were associated with less distancing; no significant associations were found for gender or age.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Change in average county mobility (pp; negative = more social distancing) per IQR increase in per capita income
Change in average county mobility (pp; negative = more social distancing) per IQR increase in share of Trump voters

metadata.original_paper_title: Association of County-Level Socioeconomic and Political Characteristics with Engagement in Social Distancing for COVID-19
